title: Aston Villa fan Prince William chats with players and staff as he visits his team training ground
body_text:
Thumbs up for his sporting heroes! Beaming Aston Villa fan Prince William chats with players and staff as he visits his team's training ground
- Prince William has supported the Birmingham-based team since childhood
- READ MORE: Prince William reveals why Princess Diana would be 'disappointed'
The Prince of Wales appeared delighted today as he visited Aston Villa's training ground.
Prince William, 40, who has supported the Birmingham-based team since childhood, was seen chatting and laughing with players at the Bodymoor Heath centre in Warwickshire.
He met CEO Christian Purslow, Head Coach Unai Emery, his coaching staff and the men’s first-team squad during his outing today. He also spoke with Villa Women Manager Carla Ward.
A beaming William watched the team while they were training and gave them a thumbs up at the team's grounds.
The Prince was not sporting his football kit though, opting for a more smart look wearing a navy blazer, a royal blue sweatshirt, smart black trousers and some brown shoes.

Meeting his heroes! The Prince of Wales spoke to Aston Villa's men's first team squad on the pitch today
The Aston Villa official Twitter account shared the images with the caption 'Up the Villa', which the Prince and Princess of Wales' official account retweeted.
The father-of-three was the football club's guest of honour when the ribbon was cut at the new £6million facility in two years ago.
He has attended numerous games and was even present at the victorious play-off final over Derby County at Wembley in 2019.
His visit comes before Villa's Premier League match with Bournemouth this weekend, as they hope to make the top half of the table.
William looked cheery as he met Unai Emery on the pitch along with the players.
Prince William is president of the Football Association (FA) and took over the role from his uncle, the Duke of York, in 2006.
William has taken a keen interest in all aspects of the game, including his support for the men's and women's national teams.
He previously spoke out about why he is a fan of the club, and told the BBC in a 2015 interview: 'A long time ago at school I got into football big time.
The father-of-three met with CEO Christian Purslow and Villa Women Manager Carla Ward

'I was looking around for clubs. All my friends at school were either Man United fans or Chelsea fans and I didn't want to follow the run of the mill teams.
'I wanted to have a team that was more mid-table that could give me more emotional roller-coaster moments.
'Aston Villa's always had a great history. I have got friends of mine who support Aston Villa and one of the first FA Cup games I went to was Bolton v Aston Villa back in 2000. Sadly, Villa went on to lose to Chelsea.
'It was fantastic, I sat with all the fans with my red beanie on, and I was sat with all the Brummie fans and had a great time.
'It was the atmosphere, the camaraderie and I really felt that there was something I could connect with.'
